cards.front: Rise time t_r for first-order circuit?
cards.back: t_r = 2.2τ. Time from 10% to 90% of steady state. Derives from t_r = τ·ln(9).
After 1τ: 63.2% complete. After 3τ: 95%. After 5τ: 99.3%. Uses e⁻¹ = 0.368.
Tangent at t₀ reaches x(∞) at time t₀ + τ. Graphical method to find τ: draw tangent, see where it hits steady-state level.
t_k − t_j = τ·ln[(x(t_j)−x(∞))/(x(t_k)−x(∞))]. Finds time between any two points on the exponential curve.
Sign of τ. τ > 0: stable (decays to x(∞)). τ < 0: unstable (grows exponentially). Negative τ = positive feedback = runaway.
BW × t_r ≈ 0.35 for first-order systems. Knowing one gives the other. f_3dB = 0.35/t_r.
After 5τ, response within 0.7% of steady state. Used as practical settling time in circuit design.
Solve segment by segment. Each segment: new x(t₀) = final value of previous segment, new x(∞) from new source value, same τ.

cards.front: Inspection method: what guarantees all branches share τ?
cards.back: Substitution theorem. Replacing C with source v̂(t) shows all quantities are linear functions of the exponential with the SAME time constant.
Op-amp with positive feedback. R_TH becomes negative → τ = R_TH·C < 0 → exponential growth → output saturates at supply rails.
